item.title: The Only Escape
item.description:
series: Exodus #

verse: Exodus 14:15-31 #

Main Idea: #

True freedom is to live on the boundary of goodness. How do we escape the enslavery of sin and ourselves? God didn’t just deliver the Israelites to be freed from the Egyptians. He rescued them for the purpose of being God’s people. It wasn’t the power of the Israelites that brought their salvation. It was by walking in the path that God has opened for them.

item.title: Only Be Silent
item.description:
series: #

verse: Exodus 14:1-14 #

Context: #

The Israelites had just fled Egypt through the leadership of Moses, but they are being chased down by Pharaoh and his guards. The situation turns for the worst when the Israelites find themselves pinned against the coast of the Red Sea.

Prelude: #

PJ’s son (roy) spilled water while eating at dinner. It’s been a recurring pattern at home and at day care. PJ felt that no matter how many times he told Roy to, “be careful”, that he would never learn. And this time, PJ blew up and yelled at his son. The pastor’s frustration had built up and led to a reaction. How often do we as humans react first before thinking? It’s a natural tendency for us.

item.title: Three Foundations for a Satisfied Life
item.description:
series: #

verse: Exodus 13:1-22 #

Main Idea: #

Today we will look at spiritual practices that aren’t just helpful, but foundational to a joyful and satisfying Christian life. It will shape you to live faithfully and wisefully, even in times of uncertainty.

Context: #

The Israelites have finally escaped Egypt after the 10 plagues and are beginning their journey through the wildnerness.

Foundation #1: First is for the Father #

Found in verse 2, God says to mose, “Consecrate to me all the firstborn…”. This commandment is saying that the first and foremost is for the father. It’s not referring to control, rather prioritizing a relationship with God. Our lives are objectively undeserved. One man suffered a terrible death so that we may live. Consecrating the first born is a constant reminder of the great act of Jesus to die on the cross for our sins. Note that you cannot serve two masters. Often times we chase after worldly things such as money, sexual validation, etc., but no matter how much of those things we possess, the dopaminergic feeling eventually fades. There’s an alarming statistic of younger people giving much less to the church. And through survey, the findings showed that the primary reason behind this is that younger people stopped trusting that the church would use the donation wisely. But the unfortunate reality behind this lack of trust is that we fail to practice the act of giving faithfully and sactificially. The Bible teaches us that the more we give the more we will receive back, whether directly or indirectly. If you’re in a spot where you just absolutely cannot trust your Church with your money, please go find a new church and pour yourself out there.

item.title: sodijf
item.description:
guest speaker: Rev. Yuijun Lee (Lead Pastor of Chara Community Church in Virginia) #

verse: Nehemiah 3:1-2 #

Context #

The book of Nehemiah is an incredible book bc it connects the old testament to the new testament. This story is written in the context of Isreal being destroyed by Asyria and Babylon. Every single house, living area, market, street, and even the very iconic building of Israel (the temple of Jerusalem) were all annihilated. Nehemiah is about restoring people out of nothing through God’s goodness and faithfulness. Note that in this entire memoir, Nehemiah’s name is never mentioned, not even once. The purpose was to put a focus on the next writer – Luke.

item.title: Already Enough
item.description:
series: #

verse: Exous 12:1-13 #

Intro: #

Flushing the toilet in albania was mad awkward and ineffective? PJ also had trouble completing assignments because of technical difficulties with the laptop battery. Despite all of these difficult experiences in Albania, it ended up alright. This is because as humans, we can adjust. When PJ moved to the U.S, it felt like Heaven. He felt really blessed, but also undeserving of all this goodness. But the longer he lived in the U.S., the slowly became more desensitized. And this is an analogy for how as Christians, we become desensitized to the grace of the Lord.

item.title: Unsung Hero
item.description:
series: guest speaker #

verse: 1 Samuel 14:1-15 #

In the verse, we find a character named Jonathan who was courageous because of his unwaivering faith in God. But there is another character, the nameless armor bearer. He was a key factor in Jonathan’s success.

Main idea: #

The unsung hero is someone who receives little attention but has contributed much to the success of a team. Park Jisung is a good example of a player on Manchester United that humbly assists others. Everyone has a desire to be recognized for their good work.

item.title: Deliverance Through Disappointment
item.description:
series: The God who remembers #

verse: Exodus 5:1-23 #

Main Idea: #

In the previous chapter, for the first time in decades, Moses receives a greater calling. To take his family to return to Egypt and do the work of God. Moses was convinced to take action, at the cost of a comfortable life. But Moses was unsuccessful at persuading Pharaoh and resulted in the Israelites living an even more difficult life. He begins to doubt himself and God and says, “Why have you sent me here?”. Disappointment is inevitable. It can even come from God. Why does God deliver us from disappointment instead of preventing it? Why am I constantly disappointed?

item.title: Failure Before Power
item.description:
series: The God who remembers #

verse: Exodus 4:18-31 #

We see that Moses stumbles and fails before he was used by God.

Main Idea: #

We often create a narrative presumptuously, and we have a pride to protect that notion. And this can unfortunately lead us to stubbornly miss out on opportunity. But to avoid this, we have to fail. Failure often comes first, but God’s power will follow succintly after.

item.title: Responding to the Resurrection
item.description:
guest speaker: Pastor Thomas #

verse: John 20:11-18 #

Mary sees Jesus at the tomb but doesn’t recognize him. She’s there early in the morning before sun rise and demands to see him.

What is the proper response to the resurrection? #

It’s a lifestyle of worship. Which means every aspect of our lives is glorifying to God.

Make worship into a lifestyle through commitment #

This means prioritizing God even when it’s inconvenient. Waking up early to pray, volunteering, sacrificing the weekend, etc. We need to remind ourselves constantly the magnitude of the resurrection, and if you truly believe in it, then there should be a genuine change reflected in our identity and actions. You need to devote yourself to Christ, regardless of the circumstance.

item.title: Trusting God with my Miracles
item.description:
series: Regen church Easter service #

verse:

What is Easter about? #

It’s not about our kids. Not about the bunny, candy, festivities, or whatever. Yeah it’s exciting, but that’s to make it memorable for the young ones. As you get older, you’ll begin to understand the true meaning of Easter which is the resurrection of our savior and creator and Lord Jesus Christ.

How we know Jesus not only walked the Earth, but is truly our savior? #

Jesus fulfilling the prophecies foretold in the old testament had criminally low odds. Insurmountably low. 500 witness accounts of Jesus rising from the dead. Half brother James believed even tho he doubted his whole childhood. The 12 disciples died because they believed. There is definitive evidence that Jesus existed. And there is beyond a reasonable doubt that he defeated death.

item.title: Cost of Following Jesus
item.description:
series: epic large group #

speaker: pastor young #

verse: Luke 9:57-62 #

To follow Jesus, we have to be willing to sacrifice #

As seen within these verses, a man wants to follow Jesus, but has important things to do such as saying good bye to his family or burying his father. And yet Jesus calls him to drop everything and still follow him. It is difficult to make a promise to Jesus that you will follow him earnestly. You have to be ready and willing to sacrifice everything that you desire to carry out his plan. But sacrifice doesn’t have to be impossible or incredibly difficulty. On the contrary, sacrifice can be an opportunity to show your love and devotion. We are presented with opportunities to sacrifice for Jesus everywhere we go, it is up to us to take it. Be careful that you don’t think of sacrifice as draining or taxing on oneself. You may believe that constantly sacrificing oneself will eventually lead you to feeling burnt out, but this shouldn’t be the case because our God is empowering us and will allow us to do whatever is possible.

item.title: Divine Disruption
item.description:
series: The God who remembers #

verse: Exodus 3:1-4 #

Moses is running away after killing an Egyptian worker for mistreating a Hebrew. In this set of verses, Moses finds an eternally burning bush.

  • Note that we, in hindsight, easily consider this a miracle. However, in the moment, it is not so easily observed.

Main Idea #

There are moments when we go to God asking for something we desire or feel like we need. But sometimes God answers us by making life more difficult/troublesome. There are often things that we don’t realize need to be addressed until God tells us they need to be fixed.

item.title: The Alabaster Flask
item.description:
series: College group #

verse: Mark 14:1-11 #

Context: #

-In this verse we find a woman who pours an alabaster flask which is worth a year’s wage and dumps it on Jesus. It’s an expressive act that emphasizes her love for Jesus Christ. This in juxtoposition to Judas betraying Jesus for mere dollars demonstrates how being faithful to Christ will cost us in a worldly sense, and rejecting God will barely provide benefit to us in the worldy sense.

item.title: Seeing as God Sees
item.description:
series: The God who remembers #

verse: Exodus 2:1-10 #

Context: #

  • The story of Moses’ birth. His mother hid him in the reeds and the Phaoroh’s daughter decides to spare his life. She names him Moses because she, “Drew him out of the water”
  • Admist a chaos for the Israelites, the mother of Moses sees it differently.
    • Instead of fearing for her child’s life, she instead has a vision similar to God’s.
  • It’s important to note that the mother deems her son as, “Fine” or in Hebrew, “Tov”. Which directly translates to Good. This echos the ideas from Genesis 1, where God found things Good. It wasn’t about the child’s physical appearance. It was about his character and she found it good.

Main Idea: #

Obviously as humans, we have a tendency to react things in a worldly manner. But how much more joyful and at peace could we be if we saw things the way God sees it?

item.title: Where is God in this?
item.description:
series: The God who remembers #

verse: Exodus 1:1-22 #

Main Idea: #

“You won’t find any mention of God, miracles, signs, or any amazing parables. Rather hardship, suffering, oppression. But you will see that God is still deeply in work.”

Why is God silent sometimes? #

To give us hope to something greater. Contextually, the Israelites have experienced an absence of God for roughly 400 years. In verse 1, we see the geneological descendants of Abraham in order to show that God is working on the promises he made back in Genesis. God is always there. And he has a masterful plan. God builds slowly. We see that the people nation of Israel grow to great heights. God has been faithfully helping them multply and grow into a nation. God silently aided the Israelites.

item.title: Spiritual Discipline
item.description:
series: Silence and Solitude #

verse: Mark 6:30-32 #

Main Idea: #

The world is fast, we prioritize speed and efficiency. If we don’t take time to recognize God and feel his presence, life and time will slip right past you. We need moments to absorb and reflect what we’re going through in order to avoid the effect of missing what is happening or recognizing what you’ve been through.

item.title: Waiting Beyond Time
item.description:
series: Counter Cultural Convictions #

verse: Daniel 12:1-13 #

Main Idea: #

Most people have what is called [[Time Anxiety]]. But time is a gift. Hold firmly to God’s sovereignty, trust in his plan. We need to have the courage to wait beyond time. What does this mean?

Why is time so valuable? #

How we spend our time is often how we define our identity. “Faster is better” is an idea that many people in society resonate with. Many of us believe that there is value in speed and efficiency, but we also often overvalue it. [[Time Famine]] is the idea that no matter how hard we try, we cannot accomplish everything that we desire. Time is supposed to be a gift from God for us to cherish, but it has devolved into something else.

item.title: Intimacy Over Influence
item.description:
series:

verse: Daniel 11:32-12:3 #

Context: #

Verse 32 Group of believers that resisted the temptation. Verses 36-45 Future ruler (antichrist) is foreshadowed. King is exalting himself proclaiming that he is the god of gods.

Main Idea: #

Humans have an inherent desire to belong.

  • People are drawn towards comfortable and relatable people.
  • But the reality (and potential pitfall) of church is that we can potentially start prioritizing the community, which in turns prioritizes ourselves, over God.

We as Christians simply don’t pursue intimacy over influence.

item.title: Confession Not Conformity
item.description:
series: Anchored in hope, rising in faith #

verse: Daniel 9:1-23 #

Main Idea: #

The church has been on a decline, but it can be reformed. Not by conforming to the world, but by confessing our sins to God. If people want to see a revival of the church, it has to start with every individual member. What does a revived church look like? God’s glory is revealed through each individual person.

item.title: Courageous Consistency
item.description:
series: Anchored in hope, rising in faith #

verse: Daniel 8:27 #

This terrible ruler, the king of Greece, was desecrating the church and persecuting the Jews. Daniel had a terrible vision of this that it brought him illness. But even then, we find that in verse 27 that he rose and “went about the king’s business”. He remains courageously consistent although he was facing overwhelming fear and hardship.

item.title: Resting in the Unknown
item.description:
series: Anchored in hope, rising in faith #

verse: Daniel 7:15-28 #

Context: #

  • A man receives a direct vision from God.
  • The ‘ancient of days’ executes judgment.
  • Daniel holds on to the tension of not knowing. He doesn’t demand understanding, but instead continues to rest in both the unknown and peace.

Main Idea: #

People are generally restless with the unknown. We seek answers at every turn. But finding the answer won’t result in peace. Often times the answer isn’t clear, thus the increase in knowledge leads to confusion.

item.title: Persistent Prayer
item.description:
series: Anchored in hope, rising in faith #

verse: Daniel 6:10 #

Context: #

  • King Darius persian ruler
  • Daniel is old now ~80 years old
  • People were trying to dig up dirt and find any flaw in his character. The only way to take Daniel down was to attack his devotion to God.
  • “For 30 days, let nobody worship anyone buy you. If you break this law they will be thrown into the Lion’s den”
  • Daniel is being asked to temporarily stop praying for God. Realistically he could reason and say that this is just a small break. But no, he could not compromise this value.
  • Because Daniel disobeyed, he is theown into the lion’s den. But even in this dangerous space, he remains calm and continues to pray to God.

Main Idea: #

All people have strong grit and resilience. But where are we placing our this resolve?

item.title: Vessel of Mercy
item.description:
series: Anchored in hope, rising in faith #

verse: Daniel 5:1-7, 13-31 #

Context: #

The new King Belshazzar, the successor of King Nebuchadnezzar disrespected God by drinking from the chalices from the temple (the house of God). The feast is reckless because he’s chasing dopamine desperately before his death.

Reckless life that speaks to humanity #

What does it mean to be reckless?

  • It’s to desperately chase something with no avail. When death is imminent, it is human nature to indulge in sensuality and pleasure. Recklessness can be seen in cheating as well. People cheat because they crave and desire something that isn’t being found within the relationship.

Revelation based on this recklessness #

Wisdom can not be found anywhere in the world, only in the word of God. You are a created being by a marvelous creator. You need to turn to your creator to learn more about them.

item.title: Courage to Lose Control
item.description:
series: Counter cultural convictions #

verse: Daniel 4:28-37 #

King Nebuchadnezzar is humiliated and humbled because he was so prideful. Not just a boastful nature, but a spiritual pride.

Do we have spiritual pride? #

Spiritual pride leaves to an obsession with control. Nebechadnezzar thinks that the fruits of his labor all came by his own doing. Spiritual restoration occured when he let go of his control and gave all glory to God most high. When we have the courage release our control and pride to God, then we actually experience such great complete peace. Not just temporarily, but eternally. Letting go isn’t losing something, it’s allowing God to lead our lives.

item.title: Faithful in the Fire
item.description:
series: Steadfast faith #

verse: Daniel 3 #

Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego are cast into the fire for not worshipping Nevuchadnezzar’s idol. They survive through the power of Jesus Christ.

Main Idea: #

We are human. We have fears of failure and an expectation of loss. We all live in fire. So how can we hold on to our convictions without being consumed by the fire? Pluralism-> What we think about the most is our “god”.

item.title: Straying Away From Idolatry
item.description:
guest pastor: Pastor Myung #

verse: Exodus 32:1 #

Context: #

The israelites struggled with faith in the Lord because they couldn’t see him. While Moses was gone, they couldn’t bear to patiently wait and instead created their own God, the infamous golden calf idol.

Main Idea: #

There must only be God in our hearts when we desire to worship the Lord. There shouldn’t be any ulterior motive or something that takes precedence such as friends or the pastor. People often forget the content and information of the sermon’s from just the past sunday. Think about how many sermons you’ve forgotten in your lifetime. Being aware of this helps us to be more present and mindful towards the lessons that we are learning.

item.title: The Wisdom of God
item.description:
series: Counter Cultural Convictions #

verse: Daniel 2 #

Main Idea: #

Recognize that we are NEVER in control of our lives, no matter how much we want to believe otherwise. Ask yourself this: Where do you place our trust in today? Ourselves, our pride?

What is wisdom? #

God’s insight for the best way to live. The book of Daniel shows this when God reveals the mystery when no person of flesh could. We need discernment and insight into how God is working in our lives. Recognize that God is in control not us.

item.title: Becoming Proper Worshipers of God
item.description:
series: Anchored in hope, rising in faith #

verse: Daniel 1:1-21 #

Main Idea: #

In order for us to regain true joy, we must first earnestly strive for the restoration of worship. Joy begins with proper worship.

How can we become proper worshipers of God? #

Proper worship begins with recognizing the risk of conformity. Daniel and his friends were forced to assimilate into Babylonian culture. They had to adapt to the Babylonian lifestyle, customs, etc. They even acquired new names against their desires. We live in a time of spiritual captivity, and we need to recognize this. We are constantly surrounded by influences. It could be in the shape of a “work focused grindset community”, or a friend group that makes racist remarks. Culture can so easily be focused on sin. We can’t worship God when we induldge in all of these sins and conform to the sinful culture that surrounds you. By recognizing the risk of the influence around us, we can rely on God and make changed to our lives.

item.title: The Meaning of Christmas
item.description:
guest speaker: Pastor Myung #

verse: Luke 1:26-56 #

Main Idea: #

The meaning of Christmas:

  1. It’s the day that God showed us mercy.
  2. And it’s also the day that God showed his faithfulness

An important detail to recognize: #

Mary was afraid and felt inferior. But God empowered her saying that she is a child of God and to stand firm on your two feet.

item.title: Treasure the Word
item.description:
series: Psalm for suffering #

verse: Psalm 119 #

the longest verse in the bible. It’s the written account of David and his devout faith.

Main Idea: #

People want to make the “best” choice for themselves such as “what should we eat?”. But this created stress in our lives. But what’s a decision that we can never forget. It brings joy, peace, stability.

How should Christian’s live a holy life based on the Word? #

  1. Find delight in the word
  2. Dedictate your life to the word
  3. Look to the hopeful future and be present in the moment. The bottom line really is to simply treasure the word of God.

Can I treasure God when I don’t treasure the Word? #

I mean honestly I would find that pretty difficult. Therefore it is essential that we constantly meditate on the Word of God. Treasuring the word, following the commandments, will help you to make the right decisions and run away from sin.

item.title: Praying Our Envy
item.description:
series: Psalm for suffering #

verse: Psalm 73 #

Main Idea: #

Are you happy for others that do well for themselves or are you envious?

The heart of jealousy happens very often.

  • Don’t get caught up in focusing on what you lack. Instead look towards what you do have. This is the foundation of gratitude.

Envy is difficult to self actualize. We do it so often and we can become complacent to the feeling. As we get more discontent with ourselves, we become greedy, self pitying, and hyper critical of ourselves.

item.title: From Brokenness to Beauty
item.description:
series: Psalm for suffering #

verse: Psalm 51 #

writer: King David #

Main Idea: #

David was considered a man of God’s heart. powerful and wealthy. He was also considered a very righteous man. But like many, he fell, he commited adultery with a married woman. Nathan, a prophet, convicts King David about his sin. The story of a rich man and a poor man who had just a single lamb that he cherished very much.

item.title: Security in Suffering
item.description:
series: Psalm for Suffering #

verse: Psalms 16 #

Context: #

David calls out to God for refuge because he has been experiencing and dealing with various problems such as being a murderer and adulterer, and also because of the sins of others such as those that seek to end his life. But note that David isn’t asking for an immediate solution. Not a refuge in the sense of freedom of his problems, rather a security amidst danger. A refuge/security that cannot be shaken.

item.title: Praying through Fear
item.description:
series: Psalm for suffering #

verse: Psalm 3 #

Context: #

David is old and he’s being chased by thousands of people. His life is crumbling around him. King David commited adultery and murdered her husband and did a lot of other wrongs. Fear is not a negative emotion by itself. It can have positive effects. In 1884, Soren Keurtigard says, “fear is the response to a specific identifiable danger or threat”. Fear of failure, fear of an angry bear/.

item.title: A Call to Prayer
item.description:
series: Acting in grace together #

verse: James 5:13-20 #

Pray for one another. Don’t be afraid to ask for prayer in times of need.

Main Idea: #

Prayer has the power to change lives. If anyone is suffering in any capacity, let that man pray.

But that begs the question: Are there differences in who prays for us?

And fortunately for believers, there is. The prayer of a righteous person has a great impact. “Is anyone among you sick, so sick that the body the church cannot pray for you. Call for the elders, the leaders of the church, to come pray for you”. Now obviously this doesn’t sound necessarily good or fair on paper. “Shouldn’t everyone pray for one another?”. We’ll dive deeper into this topic later on in the sermon.

item.title: Patience
item.description:
series: Acting in grace together #

verse: James 5:7-12 #

Main Idea: #

Be patient. Some of you may not be wealthy, maybe suffering, maybe oppressed. But god is exhorting them to be patient. As sinful humans, we seek immediate gratification.

Patience -> graciousness and steadiness at the face of delayed gratifications.

Patience can also mean: Long suffering and remaining steadfast and endure and presevere.

Patience vs Stoicism #

Stoicism in practice has a lot of benefits, but one severe lacking issue is the dependence on oneself. But patience is not about willpower to withstand irritation. It’s deeper and more than that. Stoics that try not to be overwhelmed, relies on your own self. It’s not gonna work every time. If you rely on oneself, it’s not gonna work everytime. So when you do inevitably fail, you have nobody to blame but yourself.

item.title: The Danger of Wealth
item.description:
series: Acting in grace together #

verse: James 5:1-6 #

Main Idea: #

Your riches will spoil and your coins will corrode. You kept your own pockets fat at the expense of those that work for you.

Who is James condemning? #

James is addressing to a particular group of people: Christians. He’s talking about a majority of people in the church. The issue is the abuse of wealth. Hoarding it instead of using it for the glory of God. Hoarding is different than saving. Saving is encouraged by the Bible. It makes good stewards. Hoarding is accumulating so much wealth, more than necessary. Are you trying to accumulate wealth so that you can have control over your life? Trust in God, not in wealth.

item.title: The Cure for Worries
item.description:
series: Acting in grace together #

verse: James 4:13-17 #

Main Idea: #

Do not be arrogant. Don’t boast about tomorrow. Don’t talk about doing this or that, just do it. Whatever God wills you to do, just take action.

We often become so worried and stressed when things don’t go as we plan. How can we deal with this?

What causes worries? #

Forgetting God in our daily lives. Contrary to what initially comes to mind for most people, planning without God in mind is the most prevalent and common sin. When we forget God in the daily operation of our life, we assume the role of God in ourselves.

item.title: How to build Gospel centered communities?
item.description:
series: Acting in grace together #

verse: James 4:1-12 #

Last week we learned we need wisdom, especially to deal with conflicts.

Main Idea: #

We all desire change, to be better. We want to be people that are reliable and can make a positive impact. You get to experience this change, only when you become a peacemaker. When you live in close community with other christians.

item.title: A Community of Peace
item.description:
series: Acting in grace together #

verse: James 3:13-18 #

What is wisdom? #

Put simply, it’s fearing the Lord According to verse 13, Wisdom is not just known, but is shown. “Let him show his works in the meekness of wisdom.” Wisdom is:

  • Pure - Morally blameless
  • Peaceable - people who dislike conflict. Put reconciliation into action. Means to work with others even though it’s hard.
  • Gentleness - As you hear good arguments, that you are willing to change. Flexible, yielding to others.
  • Open to reason - Persuadable, a good listener
  • Full of mercy - Taking your resources and putting it to use for others in need.
  • Impartial - Show dignity and respect to all people, because we are all created in the image of God.
  • Sincere - Integrity, be wise in public and in private. We must show these things if have the desire to be wise. When we are wise, people will come to you, they will be drawn to these characteristics.

How can we implement it (how can we be wise)? #

When we don’t feel satisfied, we are constantly looking for something to make us feel content. Our life feels unsettled and dissatisfied This will lead to all kinds of evil and addictions. We find ourseleves doing things we shouldn’t be so that we can find “contentness”. But be careful that you don’t fall into the trap of earthly wisdom. Money and possessions will not satisfy you. This will only lead to more discontent and chaos.

item.title: Stop Weaponizing your Tongue
item.description:
series: Acting in grace together #

verse: James 3:1-12 #

Main Idea: #

There is an under valued importance of words and our tongue. Words are incredibly powerful and can have a lasting impact. No matter how good a person might be, our natural tendency is to speak evil than good.

Why are words so powerful? #

  • Verse 6
  • Words penetrate both the hearer and the speaker.
  • Words can destroy a life because of its lasting impact.
  • When someone curses someone, their words will sometimes turn into action.
  • When people bless you with their tongues, they often also bless you with their actions.

What do words reveal about ourselves? #

Whatever comes out of your mouth comes from the heart. It reveals who we truly are and alter the way we perceive the world. If we often speak with negative criticisms, then we will continue to perceive the world in such a light.

item.title: How can we have faithful works
item.description:
series: Acting in grace together #

verse: James 2:18-26 #

Main Idea: #

Faith without works is dead. God calls us to be a community of love. And this can be achieved even with a group of people that share no interest or have similarities. All we need is God.

What are the two common pitfalls of faithless Christians? #

  1. Christians not doing good works.
  2. Christians that do good deeds for the wrong reason.

When does work have no power? #

When it is fueled by the flesh When we try to earn God’s favor. This happens when your attitude and thought process involves pleasing God. You are also serving others, and doing it out of selfrighteousness. When it for our own benefit, the work is dead. Some common symptoms:

item.title: What kind of community is the church supposed to be?
item.description:
series: Acting in grace together #

verse: James 1:26-2:17 #

Main Idea: #

How can we act like a biblical gospel centered community?

What kind of community are we supposed to be? #

We are called to be just or merciful To not have favoritism. You need to bear the burden, do the hard thing. Treat everyone equally. How welcoming am I of others? We should be encouraged to do the hard thing. Go make the lonely feel less lonely. We need to also be merciful as in caring for those in need. Not just being kind, but meeting the needs of others. If we are not exercising mercy, and justness, we will be judged by God. We need to be merciful because it’s the foundation of our faith, God’s mercy to us.

item.title: Be a doer not a hearer
item.description:
series: Acting in grace together #

verse: James 1:22-27 #

Main Idea: #

Be doers, not hearers. Anyone who claims to be a christian and has no heart to act upon it, is not a christian. Don’t deceive yourself and truly reflect where your heart is in all of this.

How do I know if I’m a hearer or a doer? #

If you have any doubt about being a hearer or doer, you are simply a hearer. There’s no gray area or confusion. If you can’t confidently claim to be a doer, work harder to be in a position where you can.

item.title: What DOes It Mean to Live by Faith
item.description:
series: P.A Speaking #

verse: Hebrews 12:1-2 #

Main Idea: #

We should inherently be in pursuit of God. We are born to immitate, and we should be immitating that which is perfect, which is God.

We usually follow those around us though. It’s not wrong to be influenced by others, but we must follow those worth following. Though we may feel alone, you must know that we are never alone. For one, God is always with us by our side at every step of our journeys. But we should also surround ourselves with people that will bring you up. Brothers and sisters that will keep you accountable, that want to see you succeed.

item.title: How I should recieve God's Word
item.description:
series: Acting in grace together #

verse: James 1:19-21 #

19 Know this, my beloved brothers: let every personbe quick to hear,slow to speak,slow to anger;20for the anger of man does not produce the righteousness of God.21Thereforeput away all filthiness and rampant wickedness and receive withmeekness the implanted word,which is able to save your souls.

What does a biblical community look like? #

Graciously acting together. The most important part of Christian life is to be a “born again believer”. A life that is fully influenced by Jesus Christ. To be born again isn’t “sinless”, but we should have a pursuit of a different style of life. If you have truly accepted Jesus Christ, you get to experience not just eternity and salvation, but also a new freedom. He naturally changes our heart, to know what is right and wrong. We have the truth within us. The word of God is a the manual of life, a necessity. and it is pivotal that we depend on it every single day.

item.title: The Life Giving Effect of God's Welcome
item.description:
series: An inviting God #

verse: Genesis 2:16-17 #

Main Idea: #

Human souls were not made to bear outcomes. We are not in control of the way things turn out. But God does.

The Garden of Eden was a place of abundance. But contrary to popular belief, this story isn’t about restriction and limitation and rules. God asks us to care for and maintain this beautiful orchard. And likewise, weare also tasked to take part of our own responsibilities, and also enjoy the fruit. God invites us to eat until we cant anymore. This center tree is also good but we are just not ready. What this story really tells us is that, though we may be able to decide on our own, we must first look towards what God desires from us. We shouldn’t lead and take responsibility for our selves, because it is then that we become mistaken and hurt.

item.title: What is Home?
item.description:
series: An inviting God #

verse: Ephesians 5 #

Main Idea: #

What is home? Home is joy, comfort, rest, security, etc. But it can also have conflict, bitterness, frustration, and abuse. Everyone desires a home to be filled with joy… but is this possible? How do people relate to each other? How do we be more christ like?

Where should we place Jesus in our lives? #

Jesus Christ must be lord in all your relations. family, lover, employer. in everything. Have Christ be the center of your relationship. Every aspect in your life is to be grounded in Christ. This is a picture of heaven on Earth, and heaven is our home.

item.title: Being Imitators of God
item.description:
series: #

verse: Ephesians 5:1-21 #

Main Idea: #

People by nature are imitators Dont imitate the world, imitate God

How can we organically imitate God as Paul urges us to do? #

As bad as it is, to perform immoral acts (ex: spreading hate, idolatery, sexual sun), it must not even be mentioned. Media and culture has normalized these things, essentially to the point we have become desensitized. The result of all these immoralities is a weaker connection to the Holy Spirit, and a lackingness to carry out God the Father’s will.

item.title: The Power of Prayer
item.description:
series:

verse: 1 James 5:13-18 #

What does prayer do? #

The purpose of prayer is to bring healing from suffering. James 5:13 says that if you or anyone you know is ever in suffering, we should pray. Circumstantial, financial, psycholigcal, spiritual, any type of suffering. We should also pray when cheerful. Praise God for the glory he deserves. Active, vocal praise because we are joyful. Sometimes we may feel too tired or feeble to pray. That’s why you need people to pray for you.

item.title: Being Biblically Blessed
item.description:
series: Blessed to be a blessing #

verse: Genesis 12:2-3 #

Main Idea: #

We need to focus on the proclamation.

What does it mean to be biblically blessed? #

It means to have recieved something that we dont necessarily deserve. Throughout the entirety of the bible, there’s a lot of worldly blessings promissed by God. Property, freedom, and success to name a few. But we can notice that with the arrival of Jesus, we rarely find the fulfillment of these earthly blessings. Youll actually find afflictions and suffering up until Jesus ressurection. This is to show what it means to be under the blessings and provisions of God.
